'''''Cantharellus californicus''''', sometimes called the '''mud puppy''' or '''oak chanterelle''', is a [[fungus]] native to [[California]], United States.<ref name=kuo09/>  It is a member of the genus ''[[Cantharellus]]'' along with other popular edible [[chanterelle]]s.  It is generally similar in appearance to ''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarius]]'' and ''[[Cantharellus formosus|C. formosus]]'' except for its large size at maturity; individual specimens larger than {{convert|1|kg|lb}} are reported, making it the largest known species of chanterelle.<ref name=AroraDunham/>  Their unusual size is due in part to their capacity for [[indeterminate growth]], making ''Cantharellus californicus'' specimens actively grow for far longer than most other mushrooms.<ref name="BAMS"/>

==Description==
The [[pileus (mycology)|pileus]] (cap) of ''C. californicus'' is {{convert|8|–|30|cm|in}} wide or greater, and yellow-orange in color although adhering leaf litter may cause a mottled color; may become brownish with age.  The [[hymenium]] is folded into [[decurrent]] ridges (false gills) and cross-veins, which deepen with age.  The color of these ridges is usually similar to the pileus but paler.  The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] (stem) is up to {{convert|4|cm|in}} wide and {{convert|9|cm|in}} long, with coloration similar to the hymenium.<ref name=AroraDunham/>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Cantharellus californicus'' forms a [[mycorrhiza|mycorrhizal association]] with [[Quercus|oak]]s, particularly [[Quercus agrifolia|coast live oak]] in the [[California oak woodland|woodland]]s of [[Coastal California]].  It has also been found in association with [[Quercus wislizeni|interior live oak]], [[Quercus kelloggii|California black oak]], [[Quercus chrysolepis|canyon live oak]], [[Lithocarpus densiflorus|tanoak]], and possibly [[Arbutus menziesii|Pacific madrone]] and [[Arctostaphylos|manzanita]].<ref name=AroraDunham/>  ''C. californicus'' is a popular wild edible in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], and is most common between November and April.<ref name=AroraDunham/><ref name=perry08/>

==Similar species==
[[File:Cantharellus californicus 80866.jpg|thumb|left|Highly folded false gills of ''C. californicus'']]

Several other species of chanterelle may be found in western North America:
*''[[Cantharellus cascadensis|C. cascadensis]]'' — bright yellow fading to white in center of cap, associated with conifers
*''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarius]]'' var. ''roseocanus'' — false gills tend to be as dark or darker than cap
*''[[Cantharellus formosus|C. formosus]]'' — smaller size, narrower stem, associated with conifers
*''[[Cantharellus subalbidus|C. subalbidus]]'' — whitish overall color

Additionally, ''[[Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca]]'', ''[[Chroogomphus|Chroogomphus tomentosus]]'', and species in the genera ''[[Craterellus]]'', ''[[Gomphus (fungus)|Gomphus]]'', ''[[Omphalotus]]'', and ''[[Polyozellus]]'' may have a somewhat similar appearance to ''C. californicus''.  ''[[Omphalotus olivascens]]'', the western jack-o'-lantern mushroom, is poisonous and has been mistaken for chanterelles.
